Dear Ms. Boyer:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
4/5/2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be
noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and your
contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Jennifer Pastorick, Licensing Consultant
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(f) A record of any convictions other than minor traffic
violations from either of the following entities:
(i) Directly from the Michigan State Police or the equivalent state
law enforcement agency, Canadian province, or other country
where the person usually resides or has resided in the previous
5 years.
(ii) From an entity accessing either Michigan State police
records or equivalent state, Canadian province, or other country
where the person usually resides or has resided in the previous
5 years.
(i) Documentation from the Michigan department of human
services, the equivalent state or Canadian provincial agency, or
equivalent agency in the country where the person usually
resides, that the person has not been determined to be a
perpetrator of child abuse or child neglect. The documentation
shall be completed not more than 30 days prior to the start of
employment and every 12 months thereafter.
One of six new employee files reviewed lacked criminal history and central registry
clearance prior to hire date. This was on a rehire employee.
R 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and volunteers.
The licensee shall document, prior to employment, that each
employee and volunteer who has contact with residents 4 or
more hours per week for more than 2 consecutive weeks is free
from communicable tuberculosis. Freedom from communicable
tuberculosis shall be verified within the 1-year period before
employment and shall be verified every 1 year after the last
verification or prior to the expiration of the current verification.
1

One of nine employee files reviewed lacked Tuberculosis screening verification
every 1 year after the last verification or prior to the expiration of the current
verification.
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(e) Three dated references which are obtained prior to
employment from persons unrelated to the employee and which
are less than 12 months old.
One of six new employee files reviewed lacked three dated references obtained prior
to employment which were less than 12 months old. This was on a rehire employee.
The employee was rehired on 08/31/2021 and the references were dated
08/25/2020.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract/Policy violation. Please
note that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
RFCJJ 2.11 Reentry/Aftercare Services
e. Service Levels
2) Level 2: Level 2 reentry/aftercare services to be provided
when the youth does not have services provided by CMH,
another plan, or a service approved by MDHHS juvenile justice
program office.
I. Face to face contact must be made weekly for the first 30
days post release.
II. Face to face contact must be made twice a month for the
second month post release.
III. Face to face contact must be made monthly for the
remaining months.
One of two closed files reviewed did not have the Level 2 Aftercare Services
completed per contract as the facility did not complete the required face to face
contacts. It is noted there were no face-to-face contacts completed, but only
telephone follow up.
2

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 All Initial Service Plans and Updated Service Plans must be signed by an
individual that meets the social services supervisor qualifications.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
 Lakes Area is now meeting with youth as part of their admission process and
will be providing youth with information regarding the program to help them
prepare for placement. This will be documented in the preparation for
placement section and a general physical and emotional state of youth at the
time of admission.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The facility has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans during this period
under review. One CAP was in response to the 2021 Renewal Inspection dated April
12, 2021, where they were found in non-compliance for rules 400.155 (1) Initial
Treatment Plan- second repeat violation, 400.156 (1) Updated Treatment Plans, and
400.4116 (1) Chief administrator responsibilities. A CAP was approved on 4/22/2021
and was effective as those violations were not repeated during this inspection.
The second CAP was in response to special investigation 2021C0128050, with a
CAP approval dated 10/25/2021, where they were found in non-compliance for rule
400.4108 (c) Financing and audit. The agency is in compliance with their CAP, as
they are awaiting a final financial audit, they received an additional grant, and they
continue to comply with their CAP requirements.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator reported becoming the social services worker in May 2021
and then the Chief Administrator in January of 2022 as a barrier to rule compliance
for the facility. The facility implemented a new process to ensure service plans are
completed timely and report recognizing the importance of submitting a complete and
thorough service plan is instrumental in the treatment of youth placed in the program.
3

Interviews
I interviewed three youth during the onsite visit. The youth interviewed reported
feeling safe, having someone to talk to at the facility and feeling respected and
treated well by staff. The youth were all attending school. I spoke with three staff
who reported feeling supported in their job and having resources needed to complete
their job functions. There were no concerns noted by youth or staff.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on their regular license.
